title: The Birth of Computing: 1900-1950
description: Explore the origins of computing and early pioneers like Ada Lovelace, Alan Turing, and the development of the first computers.
content: This era laid the foundation for modern computing with concepts like the Turing Machine and the first mechanical computers, including ENIAC and Colossus...

title: The Rise of Programming Languages: 1950-1970
description: Discover the emergence of the first programming languages, including Fortran, COBOL, and Lisp, and how they shaped the future of programming.
content: The 1950s and 60s saw the introduction of languages like Fortran, designed for scientific computing, and COBOL, tailored for business applications...

title: The Personal Computer Revolution: 1970-1990
description: Learn about the development of programming languages like C, C++, and BASIC, and the explosion of personal computers in the 1980s.
content: With the rise of personal computers, languages like C and C++ became dominant, allowing developers to create software for an expanding tech-savvy audience...

title: The Internet Boom and Modern Languages: 1990-2000
description: Explore how the rise of the internet introduced new languages like Java, JavaScript, and PHP, shaping the modern web as we know it.
content: As the internet became widely accessible, Java brought platform independence, while JavaScript enabled dynamic web pages, giving rise to interactive websites...

title: Open Source and the Rise of Scripting: 2000-2010
description: Understand the impact of open-source software, Python, Ruby, and the importance of community-driven programming in the early 2000s.
content: The early 2000s witnessed the rise of open-source projects and languages like Python and Ruby, which emphasized readability, community, and rapid development...

title: Mobile Development and New Frameworks: 2010-2020
description: Learn about the boom in mobile development, with languages like Swift, Kotlin, and frameworks such as React Native, transforming app development.
content: The 2010s introduced a focus on mobile, with Apple’s Swift and Google’s Kotlin catering to iOS and Android respectively, while frameworks like React Native unified development...
